Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: insights into how utilities think and how they interact with other components of the energy industry
How to understand how electric utilities work in the US and how to analyze their strengths and weaknesses.
Nice, comprehensive layout of how utilities function. I liked how each class was clearly centered on one topic.
how to look at the energy sector from a utilities point of view
I didn't know a ton about utilities and learned quite a bit from the course. Some of the homework felt disjointed from the coursework however.

I felt this course provided a good overview of the current status of electric utilities in the US and enjoyed the depth and breadth that this class went into. While I was familiar with some of the material already, I felt that I was able to reinforce some key concepts throughout the course.

This course is designed to teach you about the utility industry, its challenges and opportunities. I think that I did not gain a lot from this course, as a large amount was familiar to me from other courses in the energy curriculum. However, I did gain a better understanding of the utility perspective on energy systems and pricing.

This course was so much more than a broad introduction to utilities. It was a deep dive into the impact of the changing energy sector, with various case studies (including a breakdown of rate cases) of utilities attempting to adapt. I feel well prepared for a career within the utilities industry after taking this course.

This course gave me a really solid understanding of electric utilities, particualrly how they have historically operated, and how they set rates, decide on investments, work with regulators, and can either be an ally or opponent of clean energy progress depending on local circumstances. In this way it was quite helpful.
I learned a lot about the business model of electric utilities and how they operate in relation to their regulators.
I have a better sense of how utility's make decisions
I appreciated the opportunity to expand on my understanding of utility operations, and gain Larry's insight from his time working in the space.

Gained a broad understanding of the electric utility industry and the challenges it is currently facing. In addition to industry-wide study, the course allowed me to dive into issues facing a particular utility through a case study, to explore grid issues at the ISO-NE field trip, and to consider how my team would pitch a project to a utility as a customer.

The history/structure of electric utilities, and how the industry is regulated. Cost allocation and rate design. Supply- and demand-side activities undertaken by utilities. Integrating renewable energy and the "utility of the future".
The course readings provided useful knowledge on the utilities industry. No skills were developed in this course.
I gained a basic foundation of the electric utility industry in the US.
Intimate knowledge of the electric utility industry, and how utility entities view and react to recent trends in the electric industry.
I had hoped for more finance and strategy, e.g. case studies of how utility walk though decision
Pretty well
It met my expectationts
Par for the course; a lot of survey material but I felt like Larry gave us a great sense of the industry and I enjoyed hearing his perspective and thoughts on these real issues!

This class aligned well with my expectations. I was hoping that we might spend more time on future of electric utilities and instead of focusing on where utilities have been though I understand that is also important.
The class met my low expectations.

They exceeded my expectations: I knew that I was taking a high-level course focused on a very specific industry, but I did not expect such thorough evaluation of utility options and an introduction to possible career options within the utility industry.

They were mostly in line with my expectations, and perhaps even exceeded them, as when I came into the course I thought it would be less engaging than it was based on comments from people who took it last year. I think Larry had worked to update his curriculum a bit, and I was pleasantly surprised with the range of topics he covered.
About as expected
I was hoping to dig in deeper on how utilities can (need to) transition away from their current business models. I was also hoping to get more info on utility regulations
The course spent more time on grid modernization and new energy technologies than I'd been previously told to expect, which I really appreciated.

The knowledge, skills, and insights I gained exceeded my expectations. I expected the course to be a light lift but found the material to be engaging and it helped to have opportunities for self-directed study through the project and case study. I appreciated the applied assignments, which included reading rate cases and analyzing their results.
It aligned pretty well. There are a lot of issues/concepts to cover in the electric utilities space, and I think the course was able to at least touch on all of the important ones.

I had low expectation of the course, but in reality it was even more boring than I expected. The professor meant well, and has a lot of good experience, it's just that he is an industry professional and not a professor so his style is very boring and monotonous.

Very well. I expected to learn more of the inner workings of the utility industry, especially navigating the regulatory environment, recent trends in deregulation & retail competition, and the vocabulary of utilities.

Would be better as half-semester. The movie Power Trip was fun but not a good use of class time. The assignment building rates was not a good match for students' backgrounds and interests. Better would have been something like writing up another rate case or doing mini-case studies on utility we're exploring.
The homework assignments could have been something we learned how to do or analyze first in class.

Strengths: organized, passionate teacher, nice field trip, clear lectures. 
Weaknesses: grading - it seemed like the TA or professor didn't take the time to adequately assess the homework assigned. For example, some homeworks where they really should have taken the time to look through and grant partial credit were not. Just marking a question as wrong or write without the reason why wasn't terribly helpful to the student.
I would love if the professor didn't support everything that a utility does. He must be able to be critical of some of the processes they use

I'd say some of the homework felt disjointed and Larry had great topics and lectures, just some of his slides felt overwhelmed with information. I think a key takeaway for each class could really help bring some of these topics together. Sometimes I felt a bit overwhelmed by the amount of information in each class.

I think there should be more discussion on the future of utilities and how utilities will need to change to keep up with changing electricity load and consumer preferences. I really enjoyed many of the different lectures and loved the field trip to the New England ISO.

Strengths: interesting topic, really well informed and experienced instructor, really interesting guest lecturers as well
Weaknesses: Could be more interactive. Would probably be better as a half-semester class and more guest lecturers workng on the cutting-edge of utility work

The strengths are Larry's deep experience in the industry, knowledge of the power system and regulatory process, and more broadly the role this course plays within the energy curriculum - it is a nice complement to REPF and ESA and (presumably) Energy Economics, though the latter I won't take until next year.

The weaknesses were the 3 hour block course design, combined with sometimes fairly dry material. It made it hard to fully engage at some points, and would have been easy if spread out over shorter class segments. Probably hard to actualize since Larry drives in from VT for the course and wouldn't want to more than once a week, but I do think that would improve it. Also, some of the more interesting components were when a student asked a question and Larry responded based on his lengthy experience. Somehow inserting more of his unique industry knowledge in place of some of the high level discussion of RE technologies (which we get in other courses, and for energy track students, we generally know), for example, could strengthen the course.
Some of the lectures were a little dry, but overall I greatly enjoyed the class.
The lectures are too similar to the readings, creating a disincentive to doing the reading

I appreciated the course lectures, although the slides were sometimes fairly dense. I think the course would benefit from additional discussion of energy markets and how utilities and independent power producers engage with them, given that there are limited other courses to learn about them through.

Strengths: strong foundation in the industry from a very experienced professor and ample opportunity for self-directed study through the case study and group project. Field trip was a great opportunity to discuss issues with people working in the industry. Assigned reading was very useful.

Improvements:

I really valued learning directly from a former practitioner in the utilities space, and think this was a great strength of the class. The course mostly facilitated good conversation, though at times it caused us to get behind in the lecture for that day. 

The slides were very text-heavy, and were not always very visually appealing. For such dense content material, I think a more engaging presentation format would be really helpful. 

I appreciated having guest speakers come in to speak directly about their work. 

I realize the energy sector is still rather homogenous demographically, but I would have liked to see a little more diversity among the experts whose books/articles we were assigned to read, or whose speaker sessions we were assigned to watch. For example, the Brookings Institute clip we watched for a homework assignment featured a panel of exclusively caucasian men that were at least 50 years old. I would have appreciated hearing additional perspectives from women, or people of color, or professionals that are from within my generation.

The readings were good, and the lectures touched on many interesting topics. However, the lecture style was not especially engaging, and a fair amount of time was spent repeating material already covered in the reading. The biggest drawback was that the course focused a bit too much on the traditional  utility model of the past, and not enough on innovative new utility approaches of the future. The written assignments were mostly superficial busywork that lacked analytical focus and did not teach useful skills-- it would have been better to include fewer writing assignments and make each more in-depth.

The class is a good survey of issues in the electric utility industry, but it doesn't go enough in depth.
The weakness is that the class is mostly lecture, with very little interaction with students (the instructor should ask students questions or give students exercises like role plays to mix it up).

Larry covers a lot of material in this course, so students are exposed to all aspects of the electric utility industry. However, that means he does skim over some material. It could be improved by more selectively diving into important concepts. In particular, I would have liked to see a bit more connections made between the existing utility paradigm and how recent trends that are challenging the existing paradigm, such as how the existing paradigm could be reshaped to improve and modernize the grid. Larry does a great job teaching the realities of the utility industry that prevent from some green techno-utopian visions from coming immediately to fruition, but I would have like more emphasis on grappling and overcoming these challenges.
Some material is covered in Renewable Energy Project Finance. Good for students who want to get deep into electricity generation, transmission, distribution. Not particularly quantitative.
N/A

This is a good course and Larry has a good perspective. I would say the use of it depends on how much you need to know about utilities. I wouldn't say this is a "must take" course, but one you'll learn a bit and the workload isn't too intense. A solid option for a third or fourth course, but not the one I'd say to clear your entire semester schedule for.
This is a good course for understanding the fundamentals of energy utilities, how they are designed, how they function, and where they are headed.

Take this course if you're at all interested in the energy industry. Engaging with utilities will be key for all energy projects going forward. Do the readings and engage with your chosen utility case study to get the most out of the course.
Take this class if you are interested in working for a utility some day
If you are interested in the energy sector, and particularly electric technologies, it is a valuable course to better understand utilities.
Good primer on the industry with opportunities for self-direction into specific topics of interest.

I think this is a useful course for anyone looking to go into the energy sector. It is a dense and challenging topic at times, but I think it is really valuable to have at least some understanding of how utilities are structured today, and how they are restructuring for the future.

If you don't know anything about electric utility, take this class to have a foundation. Otherwise just download the syllabus and do the readings, you can learn everything on your own without having to take the class.

If you want to go into the utility industry or a related industry (like wind or solar development), definitely take this class! If it's not directly related to your professional and academic goals however, I would not recommend this class.
